Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This course was an excellent entry into the world of intellectual history. I learned how to develop and follow philosophical arguments and articulate and evaluate the ideas of different thinkers.

I gained an understanding of the arc of Western thought over the last ~125 years and a greater appreciation for the historical and philosophical antecedents of today's prevailing ideas and debates. I learned how think about thinkers from both a philosophical and historical perspective.
Learned more per minute in this class than I have in any other class. I really learned the core ideas of the most famous 20th c European thinkers, and the threads that tie them together.
Learned a lot of surface level information on many philosophers since the Enlightenment.
The course enabled me to gain a broad but superficial understanding of some of the major figures in European intellectual thought.

I learned so much about countless European intellectuals and philosophers. I learned critical reading skills, how to be participate effectively in group discussions, and how to be clear in my writing.
I learned about the ways in which different thinkers were informed by their historical moment and how they learned from one another

This course was a great introduction to the main channels of continental thought since modernity began with the Enlightenment. While giving the ideas their full due, it was also faithful to its listing as a history course, which I think allows for a deeper understanding of the philosophical texts themselves through context and chronology. This class taught the useful skills of dissecting challenging and dense texts, putting authors and sources in conversation with one another, and articulating complex ideas succinctly and clearly. Writing skills and analysis were also developed.
Philosphy/history of intellectual thought from the enlightenment on
I developed a survey-level understanding of major European thinkers including Hegel, Nietzsche, Bergson, Marx, Lenin, Husserl, Heidegger, etc.
I learned about European intellectual history and the trajectory of philosophical thought from the 18th century.
I learned the basic currents of European intellectual thought since the Enlightenment.

I learned about so many philosophers it was incredible. After attending Professor Shore's lectures, you begin to see the way they relate to one another. In other words, you start to see the history of Western thought as a story. The class has only been over for a couple of days and I have already applied some of the knowledge I have learned to real, everyday discussion

I learned so much about the big questions of European intellectual history. I saw how each author fit into larger conversations and built upon other authors' work. The questions of subjectivity and rationality we confronted in the class helped me immensely in thinking through my ER&M and literature classes.
Gained a broad understanding of European intellectual history from modernity onwards. Did not necessarily gain any specific skills other than learning to read slightly difficult texts.
This class was very out of my normal scope of classes as a STEM major. However, I enjoyed not only the history aspect, but the different philosophies that were also present during this time.
A comprehensive understanding of modernity, post-modernity, and enlightenment thought, and the historical context that goes along with it.
I learned the ideologies that brought humanity from the enlightenment to post-modernity.
developed a strong working knowledge of European intellectual history

This class provides a broad overview of European history both intellectually and through the lenses of many social/political movements. Tracing the progression of these events through time allowed me to think critically, finding connections between thinkers of today and yesterday.

I have never taken any course relating to philosophy and got a solid background of different philosophers and the kinds of questions they are concerned with. The history part of this class really allows you to examine how this process evolves throughout time

Intellectual history is jam-packed with many theories of various philosophers and thinkers. We did not delve too deeply into the theory (which I would have liked to do), but we rather learned just enough of each thinker to get their main points and terms. In doing the readings, I learned how to read and analyze very dense and complicated philosophy.
I better understand the scope of European intellectual thought
This class gives an overview of intellectual thought. It helps you develop skills analyzing different texts and authors.
I feel like I got a good historical overview of major European philosophy movements which is what I wanted from the course.
learned the history of major ideas in modern western philosophy in their historical context - it all fits together and builds on itself and is so goddam beautiful!
I got a great overview of prominent thinkers of Europe.

This course gave me an incredibly useful baseline understanding of the general arc of continental philosophy. It also showed me how relevant philosophical thought can be to understanding history, not necessarily in the context of intellectual history, but just being able to apply some thinker's arguments to historical events.
Really great overview of intellectual history for someone who has never taken a philosophy or history class before!
I learned about philosophers and thinkers who I had either never heard of or whose writings I was unfamiliar with.

Hella knowledge. Philosophers? I know them all now. Okay maybe not all of them, but certainly more than I did beforehand. In all seriousness, this is a fantastic course and Marci Shore is brilliant. It's probably best for students who do not already have a deep knowledge of intellectual history/philosophy, but I'd imagine that even hardcore philosophy students could benefit from seeing these thinkers in historical context the way Professor Shore does.
I learned a lot more about the history of thought in Eastern Europe and I was able to digest hard-to-read texts with the help of Professor Shore's excellent lectures.
I absolutely loved this class. It was a wonderful introduction to intellectual history and lectures with Marci are actually life-changing.

Through this course, I developed a greater understanding of 19th and 20th century intellectual history, with a greater attention to the inter-relation of various philosophers, better historical contextualization, deeper understandings of epistemology/ontology and philosophy outside of political theory.

This was a survey course learned about great intellectuals and their main ideas, as well as historical context and biographical information, but not much past that. In the end, HIST 271 was exactly what I thought it'd be. A grand overview of the stage of intellectual thought since the time of Kant (the Nietzsche bit in the title is a bit misleading).
Learned about the different currents of thought that have dominated Western thought since the Enlightenment and Romanticism.

An overview of development in philosophical thought from enlightenment till post-structuralism. A strong focus on German, French and Eastern European thinkers from Hegel to Heidegger to Sartre and Derrida. I learnt a lot about the key intellectual thought of the last two centuries and also how it progressed and how it is shaped by external events.
Great understanding of general arc of intellectual thought in Europe and America from the last 200 years.
This course was a good overview into key trends in western thought since the Enlightenment. It was nice to see how great intellectuals were in dialogue and reacting to each other throughout history.
a general overview of European philosophy
This class was a great overview of some of the most important philosophers of the 19th and 20th century.
I developed a strong interest in the development of intellectual history. It was by far my favorite class at yale.

I learned all about European intellectual history and how to synthesize themes and make arguments about philosophy. I learned an amazing foundation of knowledge for basically every field that even touches the humanities.

I learned how to think about philosophical ideas in a nuanced way, as well as how historical events shaped these ideas. Prof. Shore did a really good job of pointing out the larger philosophical trends that ran through the whole course, which made everything come together.
A really solid understanding of key philosophical movements and figures since the enlightenment. An introduction to the discipline of intellectual history.
Understanding of broad themes / lineages in modern European philosophy and the lives and thought of specific thinkers.

Comprehensive introduction to 19th and 20th century intellectual history. Gained strong historical analysis skills, improved historical writing skills, greater insight into intricacies of philosophical language.
solid mix of philosophy and history

I was able to obtain an understanding of the arc intellectual thought throughout history.  Professor Shore did a wonderful job of explaining very complex ideas and providing us with a basic understanding of the most important thinkers.

The major responses in intellectual history after the death of God. The historical conditions that engendered them, and their interrelationships. Examples include Marxism, psychoanalysis, existentialism, structuralism, deconstruction.

As someone who had no background in any of these intellectual historians, this course was excellent. I know understand a lot of the references made in other classes and can make my own arguments using what I learned.
Learning intellectual history since the Enlightenment. Read works from various thinkers, including Hegel, Marx, Nietzsche, Sartre...

I learned about the discipline of Intellectual History itself, as well as of key thinkers and texts in the area of European Intellectual history. I learned how to analyze philosophical texts. I learned about the changing preoccupations of the stretch of time studied. I learned about central philosophical themes.
I loved this course; it gives you a basic understanding of a variety of philosophical ideas along with their historical contexts.
The connections between thinkers, themes, and traditions.
A comprehensive understanding of European intellectual thought.
This class if AMAZING. One of the best lectures I have ever been in. I am taking this as a second semester senior and my only regret is that I did not take it sooner. LOVE LOVE LOVE
Amazing amazing all around. Strength is the arcs Marci Shore is able to create.
The lecture handouts are very helpful for this class, and all the readings were posted online so buying any books was not necessary which is also great.
Although the material is very interesting, Professor Shore is pretty disorganized and the lectures often become repetitive.

This course was absolutely phenomenal. I learned so much. The readings were of course difficult but incredibly manageable and interesting to discuss. The work and assignments were all extremely intentional and focused on helping each student learn.

The course spanned a great amount of time so I thought at times so important people werent touched on enough. Besides that I really loved this course I enjoyed each of the classes thoroughly and look forward to them.

This is a rigorous course, and there is nothing glaring that I would change about it. The readings are as concentrated as possible which makes it very easy to keep up with them. The lectures are mesmerizing.

This is one of the best classes I've taken at Yale. Marci Shore is a great lecturer and I really liked that she didn't use slides. The exams were very fair because she gives sheets with the terms/quotes you need to know. The midterm essay was fun and interesting to write. I'm a STEM major and this class was a great way for me to get involved in the humanities.

Professor Shore's lectures were generally excellent and engaging. However, I found that the midterm was far too rushed in class and the second half of the course felt much more disjointed than the first.

Strength I think would be the quality of teaching from Shore and the TAs. I found the lectures incredibly thoughtful, relevant, and structured. Weakness would probably be that after spring break, the course lost its linear trajectory and got a little confusing.

Strengths: interesting thinkers. Weaknesses: a terrible topic for a big lecture. Readings were dull and it was clear no one really did them for section, and the class was too big to get much out of the ideas or really connect with the material.
The lectures are excellent. The readings are challenging, but not overwhelming in terms of length. Class discussions, at least in my section, were very engaging.

The lectures were always engaging, always got me excited about the material. That being said, they were often totally impenetrable. I often left lecture bewildered as to the basic content of the course. It took office hours, individual review, and study groups to fully understand the material.
Strengths were definitely in the lectures and readings. I would argue for fewer authors, more reading, and less biographies on the authors.

The midterm was extremely challenging because of the time constraint. I found that 50 minutes for 6 IDs and an essay was quite unreasonable, and because of the time constraint I was not able to think critically about the essay question, but rather just had to regurgitate information.

We got to read primary texts of famous philosophers. Also, the lecturer is phenomenal and makes the material interesting and like a narrative. 

We did not know what was expected of an in-class history essay. Given that this is a survey introductory course and many people have not taken an in-class essay exam before, it might have been helpful to provide guidelines and samples of history essays.
strong course. don't change much. maybe keep going a little bit more toward the present (like butler/etc)
Strengths  Chronologically organized; great lectures and useful outlines

This course was great! Prof. Shore lectures well and the readings provide good insight to reinforce the material.
The classes could get a little confusing to students unexposed to the material. Ensuring that clear timelines of eventsespecially the more unfamiliar ones from Eastern Europeare laid out would have helped immensely.
I really liked learning about philosopher because I didnt know anything about it before.
Overall terrific; more varied thinkers would be an improvement, and so would a more clear chronology of thinkers (i.e. Levi-Strauss and Derrida).

Marci Shore is the best!!! Her lectures are like story-time from childhood. She has the best analogies to understand the philosophy and makes the theories easier to understand. In lecture, she provides multiple strategies to understand each thinker and provides the best stories about her children and and personal stories of hers from when she was a student.
The biggest weakness of this course is that we are unable to spend a lot of time on each thinker, and we just learn enough for an interesting comment at a cocktail party.
This was one of my fave classes st yale
Lecture is great. Flynn is wonderful.

The course gives interesting highlights of many important thinkers but sometimes does not go into enough depth to understand certain texts. I realize this is a side effect of having such a broad syllabus but cutting down the number of authors may allow for more time to be spent on the more difficult parts of the course.
Very great course! Professor Shore is an amazing lecturer.
Marci Shore is an amazing lecturer. Section could be better structured so it's not just reiteration of the lecture material and instead allows for deeper exploration/engagement
Strengths- entertaining, thoughtful lectures. Weaknesses- sometimes moved extremely quickly over complex concepts.

Marci Shore's lecturing is the real gem of this course, and I think she's done the best job she can in selecting primary source readings that are relevant and understandable (which is really saying something when you consider the incomprehensibility of a lot of philosopher's writing). My only complaint is section. I think that I didn't necessarily have the best TA at leading discussions, but in general I think the section felt to much like a philosophy debate rather than an intellectual history discussion. I have no idea how that can be improved, but maybe just have a better outline for TA's to lead discussion with.
The readings and lectures are structured to create a dialogue between thinkers, which is great.

I really wish the TAs were trained in phil rather than in history. Reconstructing some of the authors' thoughts in section would have been immensely valuable, but I always felt like we were too superficial, which I think was because the TAs were not that much more familiar with the authors than we were.

Strengths: You learn about the most important thinkers, basically from the Enlightenment through the 20th century. While, as other reviews note, this may help you out at cocktail parties, it genuinely introduced me to new perspectives that I'm sure I will continue to think about for the rest of my life.
This course is amazing, the lectures are fascinating and engaging and the sections were well conducted.
I wish she would give us outlines of her lectures but everything else was fabulous.

Strengths: Excellent syllabus, engaging lectures, and my TA was strong, both helpful and directing sections well. 
Weaknesses: Not enough of the grade is determined by the Credit/D deadline to make decisions on the course. Would have appreciated less breadth and more depth at times with respect to the material (i.e. only focus on 19th and 20th centuries as opposed to Enlightenment).

Strengths: The handouts were very helpful, and Professor Shore sent us a lot of supplementary emails about extra events we could attend if we were interested. 

Weaknesses: Some of the lectures felt like Professor Shore kept on repeating ideas over and over again, and I think she could've made better use of the time we were together, sometimes.

Lectures are fun and informative, but they always left me wanting to learn more because they often lacked substance. Section discussions are engaging, but there will be no in-depth discussions of philosophy or theory because they are meant to check that you've done the readings and gone to lectures.
Recordings of the lectures would be extremely helpful as it was hard to catch everything the first time around, especially without typing on a computer. The lectures were generally fantastic!

A good coverage of important European thinkers of 19th-20th Century, we learnt about their key philosophies and how they interacted with each other. The content is very eye-opening however it is a pity that we could not go in depth for each thinker. Most of the time our understanding of the philosophy stops at what is covered during lectures.

Since the course had a wide scope, we didn't get to dive into too much depth but the key concepts were covered in sufficient detail for a good understanding. Overall, lectures were interesting and enjoyable but some lectures were significantly better than others. I think students might better engage with the material through more assigned essays rather than just one essay and two exams. Many of the ideas require a lot of thought and in a timed exam setting students may not be able to present interesting and complex arguments.
great lecture
Truly only strengths; this course gave me goosebumps, and it reshaped the way I think of history.

Strengths: Syllabus, lectures
Weaknesses: None

I think this course was really accessible for everyone (I am a STEM major and I had little experience with philosophy), and Prof. Shore made the subject material interesting no matter what background you come from. She was a fantastic lecturer! Her weekly study guides/lecture notes were also very helpful for following along with the material. Some of the ideas were a little over my head, but I think that is the nature of the subject material more than the lecturer.

Strengths: brilliant professor, exceptionally engaging, compelling, informative lectures, these lectures really are unforgettable. overflowing with substance and the drama of the course material. section discussions were interesting. 

Weaknesses: this was almost a perfect class. I could have gone for a little more explanation of the organization of the last few lectures.

Strengths: lectures are awesome. I'm always excited to hear the next one.
Weaknesses: It's a survey course, so understanding of some thinkers is going to be a bit sketchy. I would have liked help digging into the harder readings (Hegel, Heidegger) more line-by-line rather than hearing a nice exposition of their thought and then not being able to connect it with the reading really. Also seemed like there were some big missing thinkers (Schopenhauer, Kierkegaard, Wittgenstein, all Analytic Philosophy). These may not be professor Shore's areas of expertise, but would have been nice to at least mention them and hear how they fit in.

Strengths: very strong lectures, Professor Shore is extremely engaging and makes complex subject matter accessible.

Weaknesses: moved very quickly but expected from an introductory survey course, readings varied in length and difficulty week by week
lectures were good but section was lacking

Strengths: (Somewhat ironically for a class that ends with skepticism of all narratives) Prof Shore has a very strong narrative thread in her lectures from Enlightenment to Deconstruction. Her lectures are extremely engaging and she manages to make complex thinkers easily understandable

The lectures given by Professor Shore were definitely the highlight of this course. They were 90% engaging and really left you with a lot to think about after each one. It would help if the handouts with the names highlighted the most important names and not just everyone Professor Shore mentions.
I am extremely happy to be exposed to so many great Western thinkers in this course.

More papers less exams! I felt like I got a lot more out of writing the one essay than I did completing the tests. I liked getting to play around with the ideas and thinkers I found the most interesting.
This course was absolutely wonderful. I loved the thinkers studied. The lectures and sections were both engaging. Professor Shore's teaching was outstanding. I have no criticism.

Strengths include the amazing lectures and interesting readings. Weaknesses do include the basic nature of some of the seminar discussions; often the information was not delved in enough to reinforce ideas for students.
Overall a very excellent course. I have no recommendations for improvement.
Yes! This lecture is amazing. Prof. Shore breaks down each concept so that it is easy to understand and the progression of thought becomes simple and clear.
Absolutely!!! You'll learn the core ideas of the most famous 20th c Western thinkers. Shore simplifies hard ideas into simple ones. Super interesting and helps with all other humanities classes.
Yes
Absolutely. It gives a fantastic perspective on the scope of philosophical thought as it has developed throughout the past few centuries.

THIS CLASS SHOULD BE REQUIRED FOR ALL YALE STUDENTS. This is such an amazing class I can't even begin to explain. First of all, Marci Shore has to be one of the most brilliant people on the planet. She is an incredible lecturer. I left most of her lectures with my jaw dropped and with goosebumps. The readings were difficult but not that long and were so incredibly interesting. The assignments were manageable and very intentional (not at all annoying, you never feel like you are doing busy work). I feel like this class changed my life. The material that you learn is so applicable to everyday life.
I would recommend it because I enjoyed the classes thoroughly but I would warn them that the material is at times difficult

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone at Yale. We are an intellectual bunch of people here at Yale, and it is endlessly valuable to have a basic understanding of not only the basic theories that have informed Western dialogues in the past two centuries, but also the context out of which they arose. Regardless of where you go in life, these ideas will be useful at cocktail parties at worst and in everyday life at best, in the case of a career in the humanities.

Yes! Whether or not you are a humanities major, this class is a great way to get to know a lot of thinkers that have influence on politics/intellectual thought today. It will really make you see the world differently. The lecturers are almost like mini performances - everyone claps at the end. I got a lot out of this class.
I absolutely loved this class and I think it was the perfect way to cap off my senior year. Professor Shore is wonderful and the lectures were so clear, enjoyable and insightful.
Absolutely. Best class I've taken at Yale, hands down.

One of the best history courses I have taken. The lectures were incredibly and every idea is placed in an overarching dialogue. You cannot escape dialectics. Your understanding of History will be all the better for this class.
Yes -- it's a good fifth class if you come to lecture and keep up with the ideas.

I would definitely recommend this class for someone that wants a good overview of western philosophy. It was engaging and intellectual stimulating. Marci Shore is a great lecturer who is able to bring the material and relate it back to the contemporary moment. The readings are actually pretty interesting and the section discussions are productive. The only complaint is that this really is a survey course so don't expect to really know the philosophies in and out, but rather just the general idea.
Yes! Must take.

Everyone should take this class. The only downside is your friends will get annoyed with you saying everything is a Hegelian dialectical. In all seriousness though, the course was fascinating and shockingly applicable to daily life. Really gets you to think.
Not really, it's kind of a bland course, especially for such interesting material. Would've been much better in a seminar!

Yes take this course! I am not a history major, but I found that the ideas expressed by the various thinkers have definitely influenced the themes I write about in my creative non fiction. Essentially, it gives you a framework by which to analyze the world around you. You'll find that many of the concepts addressed in class apply to what you see on the news, and you'll be able to give a name/origin to what you are observing.
YES! The lectures are impenetrable, but if you put in the effort to understand the material, you will be rewarded with a much deeper understanding of pretty much any conversation in the humanities.
Yes. I think if you are unsure as to what you want to study in history, this is a good survey course.
Yes! I think this is a great class, but maybe not for a STEM major just trying to get a HU credit.
Yes!! An amazing class, even for people who think philosophy isn't their thing.
Yes, the material helps motivate many ideological trends and history events in the past. The class puts all of history in perspective.
I would recommend this course. The lectures are all very interesting and engaging and the workload is very reasonable.
yes, if they want to take it
Definitely take Intellectual History! It's an insightful course that you will learn from even if you are already familiar with the philosophers.
Yes! Take this class if you want a great introduction to modern philosophy and understand the Western intellectual tradition. Marci Shores lectures are captivating.
Intellectual History was fantastic. I dont particularly like philosophy, but I loved the way in which Professor Shore presented itas a series of historical trends and developments.

Yes absolutely! Be prepared to be confused for a while until it all clicks. During the semester, I had points where I grew frustrated with the unintelligible writers (e.g. Derrida), but it paid off. It just takes time to percolate (Professor Shore is right about that one), but once it all comes together, it is fabulous. It really addresses the largest themes of modernity.
Absolutely it provides a perspective on the big questions of life
Yes
This is an interesting course but you need to do the readings to get the most out of the course. Can be a good fifth credit and is not a lot of work for a Cr/D.
Its a good fifth credit, but it isnt going to revolutionize your life or way of thinking. The class is interesting enough to not dislike it, but I wasnt a huge fan either.
Yes! Take this course! Even if it just CREDIT/D. Professor Shore gives you the tools to take on historical and intellectual figures that are notoriously challenging and difficult.
this class blew my fucking mind ... I would call it a don't-miss
Yes, take it as early as possible! Really helpful background info going in to all other humanities courses at Yale.

I think this course is absolutely worth taking. I'm definitely not a philosophy person, and to be quite frank I'm still not, but having at least the basic understanding of continental philosophy that I've gained from this course has already benefited me in other courses. Marci Shore is a fantastic lecturer, and the reading load isn't particularly heavy and always feels relevant to the course (even if it is dense and somewhat incomprehensible sometimes). The paper is annoying, but not particularly bad, and the exams were definitely fair. Overall 11/10 would recommend.
Yes; it provides an interesting background in continental philosophy to those who either do not know anything about it or want to approach it in a new way.

I would absolutely recommend this class. Marci Shore does an amazing job at providing solid familiarity with canonical thinkers of the modern Western tradition. The questions that the class goes into have very consequential stakes, which is why this class is one of the best classes Ive taken at Yale. The class essentially throws at you the crisis of Modernity: what happens when we kill off God and have to deal with the massive epistemological, ethical and ontological void that it brings along? Europeans desperately tried to fill this void for about a century, a journey that is both extremely insightful and moving to reconstruct. Marci Shore does an amazing job at making you feel the angst, pain and frustration that goes along this history. This makes the class depressing at times (if the first half of the class does not make you a nihilist, then either you have an unshakable faith in God or youre not taking the death of God seriously; I am now convinced that secular morality is impossible), but some comforting ideas can be found along the way (I personally found solace in French existentialism).

Aww helll yee. You get exposed to so many different ideas that have shaped the course of history, which will generally make you more knowledgeable, and hopefully inform your outlook on life and the world. Also, people freaking clap at the end of Professor Shore's lectures she's so good. Lastly, the readings are excellent (with the exception of Husserl because he was a great thinker but a crap writer), but you can certainly do well without doing all of them, and probably even any of them, if you really don't have the time.
Yes, Professor Shore is an amazing lecturer and the material is both very fascinating and important.
Absolutely. Lectures were amazing and Marci Shore is a Yale Gem. TAKE THIS BEFORE YOU GRADUATE.

Yes, I would recommend this course to other students; its particularly useful to those earlier on in their Yale careers, but even as an EP&E major whos taken quite a few political philosophy courses I still got quite a bit out of this one through exposure to philosophers outside of political theory. The course covers European Intellectual History from the Enlightenment onwards but more particularly since Nietzsche and the Death of God. Lectures are engaging, my section leader (Carolyn) was quite good, and the readings are definitely worth doing. I took this in a busy semester, but I may suggest not doing so as you will get more from the course if you engage more fully.

Yes; I feel like we go through college hearing about thinkers like Nietzsche and Arendt and such but don't really understand their ideas. I guess it's easiest just to pick up a book and read about this kind of stuff, but if you're looking for a relatively laid back fifth course, go with this one.

I can't recommend this course to anyone with a background or a deep interest in the subject matter, particular those who have studied philosophy. The course offers a great reading list, but ultimately treats interesting philosophy in a basically unphilosophic way. You come away with a handful of scattered notions about the thinkers studied, but none of the meat of their thought. That might sound like a tall order, but I think it would be within the reach of a different professor. And if the philosophical substance wasn't there, at least we could have had a good biographic understanding of the authors. But even this was lacking. 
What is perhaps most disappointing is that the course fails to convey a sense of the rigorous connection from author to author, as if we hadn't even grasped the *beginning* of the question of making an intellectual history. Doing an intellectual history is a philosophic act and Professor Shore is not a philosopher, after all.

I'd absolutely recommend this course. Fantastic overview of philosophy since the enlightenment. The lectures are superb, and the material I learned in this class was applicable in all the other classes I took this semester.

Highly recommended. A good overview of the important philosophy movement in the last century and a good jumping board from which to explore the individual thinkers in depth. Many of the philosophical thoughts also prompted self-reflection about what is the meaning of life.
Yes!
Yes!  Super fun and almost no work
Yes!! This was one of the best classes I've taken at Yale. Marci Shore is absolutely amazing, engaging and makes some of the most difficult thinkers accessible. Definitely take this class.
I highly recommend this course to anyone and everyone.

I would most definitely recommend it. This has been my favorite course at Yale - no other class captures the essence of intellectual development and recounts the wonderful narrative of Europe with such acumen and taste.

This class gives you an incredible foundation of knowledge about all the major thinkers in European history since the French Revolution. Would strongly recommend. Knowing a little bit about Hegel, Freud, Foucault, etc, is incredibly helpful for every major at Yale. Shore is also a great lecturer- some I will remember for a long time.
A great overview of contemporary intellectual thought touching on all the major thinkers of the 20th century.

100% or more. These lectures are a phenomenon you don't want to miss. I got a really solid understanding of the Enlightenment and some of its key legacies, of existentialism, structuralism and post-structuralism from it. Recommend to people from any major.

Definitely. It's a perfect way to get real insight into a tricky topic and learn from a stellar lecturer and expert in her field. Material is interesting and it won't take much time away from your other obligations.

Yes, I would recommend this class to any humanities major looking to get a broad foundation in major intellectual themes throughout 19th and 20th centuries. I am very happy I took this class my sophomore year to inform my future studies in the history major!
yeah it's a great intro to modern philosophy if you haven't taken any before
I highly recommend this course because it will provide a foundation for seminars that focus in on a more specific topic.

The singular best class Ive taken at Yale. A definite must take. Shore is a one-of-a-kind Professor. Each lecturer received applause and deserved it! Absolutely a must take if you want to sound fluent on 19th century thought.
Absolutely. HIST 271 is an excellent survey class on continental philosophy. Prof. Shore is a fantastic lecturer who is able to fashion a narrative with anecdotes and philosophical arguments.
Yes! Take it and listen to Prof. Shore's incredible lectures.
Definitely!
YES. TAKE THIS COURSE. It gives a great foundation of Western intellectual history. All the readings (yes ALL THE READINGS) are very engaging and fun to read!
If youre willing to do the readings (which you should TOTALLY do bc theyre the best of the best), take it. If you dont want to read, audit the class or take it credit/D. Marci Shore is phenomenal.

I would recommend this course in a heartbeat. Of course it is not for everyone. I recommend it to students with an appreciation for big ideas, and for conversations between thinkers. I think a certain enjoyment of ideas is needed.
Yes! It fills in a lot of gaps in both one's historical and philosophical understanding of the 20th century.

Yes. This class is so much FUN. I know that for most of us, reading Heidegger and Husserl and Havel are not really synonymous with something fun. Yet, it was so  much fun to learn what intellectual movements shaped Europe, and how they responded to one another.
Yes, it helped map the intellectual history of the Western world as we know it.
I would highly recommend this course to another student if they are interested at all in intellectual history.
Absolutely. Completely changed my perception of the world.
